channel.title: CNN.com - Europe
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Europe
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Action heroes arrive on tank
item.description: Arnie, Sly, Dolph Lungren, Harrison Ford and other action movie legends from the cast of upcoming action blockbuster "The Expendables 3" turned heads on the Croisette when they rolled up it in tanks.

item.title: 5 controversial Cannes moments
item.description: Cannes has been a hotbed of controversy since the beginning. The first festival, organized by the French in 1939 as a response to the Venice Film Festival -- then a vehicle for Nazi propaganda movies -- had to be canceled after it launched on the day WWII broke out.

item.title: Kidman causes stir as Grace Kelly
item.description: Myleene Klass takes a look at opening night of the Cannes Film Festival and Nicole Kidman's work in "Grace of Monaco".

item.title: The glamor of Orient Express
item.description: In 1883, what was to become the iconic Orient Express train pulled out of Paris' Gare de l'Est on its maiden voyage to Istanbul, or Constantinople as it was known at the time.

item.title: Warhol's lost works resurface
item.description: The soup can looks familiar in an unfamiliar way, but the name at the bottom of the image is unmistakable: Andy Warhol.

item.title: From humble GIF to high art
item.description: When you think of GIFs, those never-ending sequences of looping motion, you're more likely to associate them with lightly humorous viral content than a respectable art form.

item.title: Garden of hypnotizing sculptures
item.description: Anthony Howe makes sculptures that refuse to stay still.

item.title: Nomadic world of the traveling circus
item.description: Italian photographer Giuliano Plorutti spent a decade visiting circuses across Europe, capturing performers in their downtime -- and giving us a rare glimpse into their nomadic world.

item.title: The secret to human flight? This suit
item.description: Is it a bird? Is it a plane? Actually, it's a bit of both.

item.title: From ghost town to eco-city?
item.description: In 1974, the Mediterranean island of Cyprus was divided in two. Now a group of Cypriot residents and exiles hope to bring it back together with plans to create a new Eco-city.

item.title: Hungary's best wine cellars
item.description: Eger's "bull's blood" vintages are said to offer supernatural powers. They also go well with pancakes.

item.title: Train like a Tour de France winner
item.description: As one of Kenya's premier cyclists, David Kinjah crossed the finish line winning medal after medal on several occasions. When he wasn't taking the top spot on the podium, he'd be nurturing local talent, like future Tour de France champion Chris Froome.

item.title: The world's tallest Lego
item.description: Toy brick structure reaches 37 meters over Hungarian capital to beat previous record holder

item.title: 'Vampire' burial in Poland
item.description: Popular literature would have it that the vampire's preferred habitat is Transylvania (or, if you're under 15, the slightly less glamorous Forks, Washington).

item.title: Will 'Candy Man' deliver?
item.description: The thing about presidential elections, be it in Ukraine or anywhere else for that matter, is that it makes sense to ignore everything that was said during the election campaign and, especially, in the immediate aftermath.

item.title: Russia reacts to Ukraine vote
item.description: Russia's President Vladimir Putin says Moscow will respect the will of Ukranian voters. CNN's Phil Black reports.

item.title: Far-right gains in EU vote
item.description: Far-right parties appear poised to secure a stronger foothold in the European Parliament after a vote that France's Prime Minister described as an "earthquake."

item.title: The Le Pen 'earthquake'
item.description: The headlines scream: "Political tsunami," "earthquake" and "big bang."

item.title: Putin's 48 hours in St. Petersburg
item.description: Vladimir Putin was on out on a mission here in his hometown to re-boot his languishing economy after political moves involving Ukraine scared off investors in the past half year.

item.title: King Richard III's final burial place
item.description: It's been a long journey for Richard III, the 15th century king whose skeleton was found under a parking lot in the English city of Leicester. But on Friday, his final destination became clear.

item.title: 'Radical Islamist' held for museum attack
item.description: French police arrest a man said to be a radicalized Islamist on suspicion of killing three people and gravely wounding a fourth in an attack at Belgium's Jewish Museum.

item.title: 'World's not ready to be forgotten'
item.description: The Internet has radically altered many things, not least the speed at which we all share and receive information, and the depth of the information available.

item.title: World's edge: Iceland's Westfjords
item.description: Iceland's remote Westfjords are hard to reach but its eating options and activities make it worth the ride.

item.title: Are you a psychopath?
Poland pumped by 'pope effect'
item.description: "Awesome!" exclaimed Sister Benedykta Mazur, as she described Wadowice's new museum dedicated to its revered hometown boy, Pope John Paul II.

item.title: Terror arrest at Heathrow Airport
item.description: London's Metropolitan Police confirmed that officers from the police's Counter Terrorism Command, SO15, have arrested a 19-year-old man on suspicion of preparing for acts of terrorism.

item.title: Ukraine: Donetsk left reeling after a week of violence
item.description: Pro-Russian separatists built roadblocks on the main routes into the flashpoint eastern Ukraine city of Donetsk on Saturday in an effort to prevent Ukrainian troops from entering.

item.title: Turkish cops harass CNN reporter on air at protest square
item.description: A CNN correspondent was harassed by Turkish plainclothes police as he was live on air, reporting on tensions between the officers and demonstrators on the first anniversary of mass protests in Istanbul.

item.title: Ukraine: Poroshenko vows vengeance
item.description: Ukraine's President-elect Petro Poroshenko has vowed to punish the "bandits" who shot down a military helicopter as the government's efforts to rein in pro-Russia separatists continue.

item.title: Spain arrests 6 suspected of recruiting for terror groups
item.description: Swooping in at 4 o'clock in the morning, Spanish police arrested six Spanish men on suspicion of recruiting and sending 26 radical Islamic fighters for terrorist groups in Syria, Mali and Libya, the Interior Ministry said Friday.

item.title: European cities' sewer water exposes use of amphetamines
item.description: Imagine you could let your city urinate in a cup and submit the sample to a laboratory for drug testing. Would it pass?

item.title: Manchester United owner Malcolm Glazer dies
item.description: Malcolm Glazer, owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and English soccer club Manchester United, has died aged 85.

item.title: Camps dismantled after police standoff with migrants in Calais
item.description: Police in northern France reportedly moved in Wednesday on makeshift migrant camps near the port of Calais, prompting a standoff with the defiant residents -- many of whom have fled conflicts in Syria, Sudan and Eritrea.
